ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Occassionally we had recorded lectures
N/A
Online lab simulations, Piazza discussion boards, and Ignite talk presentations
weekly discussion posts
Leminar style.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Science of art basically. How does paint come to be? How do we perceive color?

I learned about the chemistry and physics behind several art media and artistic techniques. I also learned how to give an Ignite talk (5-min presentation of 20 slides). The Ignite talks helped me improve my presentation skills.
I learned how to make and give concise, effective presentations on topics that interested me.
SO MUCH ART HISTORY! SO much science! Looking at art through a lens I've never before.
I learned alot about the work conservators do, especially, and the questions they have to think about when approaching taking care of a piece.
This course provides a scientific and humanitarian view into various art making processes, including painting, photography, paper-based works, and much more.
Learned a lot about the science behind art. It made me think of things (paintings, photos) i. a way I never had thought about.
How to give presentations and how a lot of art science works.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: really chill, homework is NOT a pset. No final exams, professor is really really sweet.
Weaknesses: class engagement was pretty low but even then professor was very understanding

Weaknesses: In the beginning, it was hard to understand our exact responsibilities and what was expected of us in the assignments. I also felt the study group/study guide was fairly pointless.

Strengths: Dr. Schilling was so understanding and supportive. Out of all my professors, she was the most responsive to our situation (pandemic, election, etc.). The Ignite talks are fun and flexible. Also, the guest speakers were amazing.

Strengths - caring and inspiring instructor, can be adjusted to suit each students' interests, especially suitable for non-STEM majors
Weaknesses - not very structured, students needed to be self-motivated, not very rigorous
PERFECT!

I think that Prof. Schilling did a great job giving us a lot of different ways to engage in this course (discussion boards, study guides, small groups, videos, readings, independent research, guest speakers), which was fun and helpful especially during this strange semester. However, at times the expectations for the course were a little unclear, and I wasn't sure what I should be prioritizing.

This course engages students with the particulars of art-making and the materials required to create a wide variety of artistic works. I think this course effectively provided real-world examples of these processes, and allowed students to discuss their own experiences with art-making. I think the online course could have engaged different online labs than the Labster modules that were used, as this technology was often hard to navigate, but it still did a good job of showing students the true science behind art-making.

The course taught a lot of information and at times it could be confusing trying to find relevance to some of the info. But in terms of scheduling it was very clear on what wed be learning every week.
More assignments that weren't presentations would be good, although I did like them. I liked how much freedom there was to choose topics that interest you.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt it worked quite well in general. The breakout room activities could be lackluster, but I get that it was an attempt to simulate in-person group work.
Lab simulations were little more than wastes of time, sadly. Discussion boards were alright, because students were encouraged to share personal anecdotes, which helped unite the class.

Guest speakers were really wonderful for changing up the rhythm of the class. Group study guides were a little difficult, given the all-virtual communication. Labsters were frustrating technologically (my computer freaked out several times, I had to redo some of the labs, and I didn't find them that helpful). I think the Ignite talks were a great idea. Professor Schilling was also very thoughtful and understanding regarding deadlines, which I really appreciated and needed this semester.

I think that the requirements for in class-participation were left a little vague for the course's virtual format, but it still did a good job of fostering collaboration between students and engaging them with the "ignite talk"-style presentations required of the course.
I think making us work in groups outside of class was beneficial because it forced us to interact with people who we would usually not.
The live sessions wowrked well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!! This is such a great science class. You do have to put in SOME effort while youre learning how to do the Ignite talks but after that, you should get better at it and itll be super easy! Its nice that we can prerecord the talks rather than doing it live. The first time I repeated my talk like 20 times and by the last talk I think I only practiced like once or twice. Its also super flexible as in you learn what YOU want to learn which is great.

Yes--it's a great science course for artistically minded people. The assignments are interesting and you can be quite creative with them. There's not too much work in the class, but the material is interesting, so I still felt engaged. We had some amazing opportunities to talk to conservators from the various Yale museums, which I loved.
Yes, if you're a non-STEM major who needs a science credit! Best suited for more self-motivated individuals - you'll get what you put into this course!
YES! Prof shilling is SO sweet and so smart and flexible!!

Good if you need a science credit and are interested in art making, conservation, or history. I think as a student who wasn't in any of those fields I sometimes felt disengaged/out of the loop. I also think this is a class that really benefits from being in person, because to be able to actually visit the museums and do experiments would really change what you get out of it.
I would highly recommend this course interested in learning more about the science behind art-making and who want to do more research into their own artistic passions.
Yes, if you are interested in art, I think this would be a great class to take cause it teaches you the ins and outs of why and how art looks the way it does.
Yes! for any non-stem majors, Professor Schilling is very open to having you work on what you're passionate about so long as it has any relevance to the course.

extras.title:
ENAS 221 01
        The Materials Science of Art
